text: Earnings Results Presentation for the Third Quarter of 2024.
Our Vision is to be the preeminent banking partner for institutions with cross-border needs, a global leader in wealth management, and a valued personal bank in our home market.
The company is focused on delivering on its Investor Day priorities through four key elements of strategy: Transformation, Investment for Growth, Simplification, and Culture and Talent.
Transformation priorities include relentless execution, regulatory remediation, modernizing infrastructure, and data enhancements.

Investment for Growth priorities include maximizing the unique global network, growing the Commercial Banking client segment, scaling Wealth, and targeting share gains in Banking, Markets, and U.S. Personal Banking.
Simplification priorities include focusing on five core interconnected businesses, exiting 14 international consumer markets, and simplifying the organization and management structure.
Culture and Talent priorities include building a winning culture, investing in talent, and delivering One Citi.

Transformation: Closed the 2013 BSA/AML Consent Order with the FRB, retired approximately 450 legacy applications, launched a new strategic Operations capacity planning tool, and continued the roll out of the strategic loan servicing platform.

Strategic Execution: Achieved a record quarter in Services, saw Markets momentum driven by strength in Equities, gained overall Investment Banking share, and experienced strong growth in Wealth client investment assets.
Progress on divestitures: On track with the separation of banks in Mexico in 4Q24 and wind-downs are ahead of schedule in Korea, China, and Russia.

Organization, Culture and Talent: Hired Achintya Mangla as Head of Financing for Investment Banking, made several significant hires in Wealth, and launched employee development programs like Resources@Citi and Development 365.

Executing with excellence across all priorities to unlock the value of Citi through driving revenue growth, disciplined expense management, maintaining robust capital and liquidity, and improving returns over the medium-term.
Returned ~$2.1 billion in capital to common shareholders through dividends and share buybacks.
Services: Achieved positive operating leverage and continued momentum with gained share across TTS and Securities Services.
Markets: Achieved positive operating leverage with strength in Equities (up 32% YoY) and strong performance in Spread Products (up 5% YoY).
Banking: Showed positive operating leverage and continued share gains of a recovering IB wallet, with DCM Fees up 75% YoY.
Wealth: Demonstrated positive operating leverage with NIR up 15% YoY and NII up 6% YoY, driven by higher investment fee revenue and client asset growth.
USPB: Attained positive operating leverage with revenue growth of 3% YoY and an efficiency ratio below 50%.
Revenues were up 1% YoY to $20.3 billion. Excluding divestiture-related impacts, revenues were up 3% YoY, driven by growth across each business.
Expenses were down 2% YoY to $13.3 billion, primarily driven by savings from organizational simplification and stranded cost reductions.
Credit Costs were $2.7 billion, largely driven by net credit losses in cards and ACL builds for portfolio growth.
At quarter-end, Citi had over $22 billion in total reserves with a reserve-to-funded loans ratio of approximately 2.7%.
Net Income was $3.2 billion, down 9% YoY, primarily due to higher cost of credit, partially offset by higher revenues and lower expenses.
Transformation investments are driving expenses to modernize infrastructure, automate manual processes, and enhance data analytics.
Business-led investments in product innovation, front office talent, and technology platforms are aimed at driving revenue growth.
Volume-related expenses are driven by marketing, transaction-related costs, and incentive compensation tied to revenue growth.

Structural and other expenses are driven by investments in risk and control, technology (including cyber and cloud), and macro factors like inflation, offset by benefits from organizational simplification.
Citi expects FY24 expenses to be in line with previous guidance of $53.5B-$53.8B (ex-FDIC special assessment and Civil Money Penalties), likely at the higher end.
Total End of Period (EOP) Consumer Loans stood at $389 billion.
Total Corporate Lending Exposure amounted to $733 billion.
The CET1 Capital ratio of 13.7% in 3Q24 was driven by strength in earnings and unrealized AFS gains, mostly offset by capital distribution and an increase in RWA.
Citi remains well capitalized with a CET1 Capital ratio of 13.7%, which is approximately 140bps above the 3Q24 regulatory capital requirement and includes a 100bps management buffer.
The regulatory capital requirement decreased to 12.1% as of October 1, 2024, driven by a reduction in the Stress Capital Buffer from 4.3% to 4.1%.
Revenues up 8% YoY, reflecting continued momentum across Securities Services and TTS.
NII was roughly flat, as higher deposit volumes were offset by a decline in interest rates in Argentina.
NIR increased 33%, driven by a smaller impact from currency devaluation in Argentina and continued strength in underlying fee drivers. Excluding the peso devaluation, NIR increased 11%.
Expenses up 3% YoY, driven by investments in technology, risk controls, and product innovation, resulting in positive operating leverage.
Credit Costs were $127 million, driven by a net ACL build of $113 million.
Net Income of $1.7 billion was up 23% YoY.
RoTCE was 26.4%; Year-to-date RoTCE was 24.7%.
Revenues up 1% YoY, driven by growth in Equity markets, partially offset by a decline in Fixed Income markets.
Equity markets revenues increased 32% YoY, driven by momentum in Prime, growth in Derivatives and higher Cash volumes. Prime balances were up 22% YoY.
Fixed Income markets revenues decreased (6)% YoY, driven by Rates and Currencies down (10)% YoY, partially offset by Spread Products and Other Fixed Income up 5% YoY.
Expenses up 1% YoY, primarily due to higher volume related expenses, resulting in positive operating leverage.
Credit Costs were $141 million, driven by an ACL build of $117 million, primarily related to portfolio mix in Spread Products.
Net Income was $1.1 billion, up 2% YoY.
RoTCE of 7.9%; Year-to-date RoTCE of 9.7%.
Revenues were up 16% YoY, largely driven by growth in Investment Banking.
Investment Banking revenues were up 31% and fees were up 44%, with increases across DCM, Advisory and ECM.
Corporate Lending (ex-gain/loss on loan hedges) revenues were up 5%, primarily driven by a smaller impact from currency devaluation in Argentina.
Expenses were down 9% YoY, primarily driven by actions taken to right-size the expense base, resulting in positive operating leverage.
Credit Costs were $177 million, driven by an ACL build of $141 million, primarily from changes in portfolio mix.
Net Income was $238 million, up 53% YoY.
RoTCE of 4.3%; Year-to-date RoTCE of 7.2%.
Revenues up 9% YoY, driven by a 15% increase in NIR from higher investment fee revenues and a 6% increase in NII from higher deposit volumes.
The quarter saw estimated Net New Assets (NNA) of ~$9B, up 267% YoY, and Client Investment Assets of $580B, up 24% YoY.
Expenses down 4% YoY, primarily driven by actions taken to right-size the expense base, resulting in positive operating leverage.
Credit Costs of $33 million were largely driven by net credit losses of $27 million.
Net Income was $283 million, up 114% YoY.
RoTCE of 8.5%; Year-to-date RoTCE of 6.8%.
Revenues up 3% YoY, driven by NII growth of 2% due to loan growth in cards and lower partner payments.
Expenses down 1% YoY, driven by continued productivity savings, partially offset by higher volume-related expenses, resulting in positive operating leverage.
Credit Costs were $1.9 billion, largely driven by net credit losses of $1.9 billion and an ACL build of approximately $45 million.
Net Income was $522 million, down 31% YoY.
RoTCE of 8.2%; Year-to-date RoTCE of 5.2%.
Revenues down 18% YoY, primarily driven by closed exits and wind-downs, as well as margin compression on mortgage securities in the investment portfolio.
Expenses down 5% YoY, as the reduction from closed exits and wind-downs was partially offset by a legal reserve.
Credit Costs were $289 million, largely driven by net credit losses and an ACL build in Mexico.
Full year 2024 revenue guidance is ~$80-81 billion, driven by NIR growth from Services, Investment Banking, and Wealth, and lower partner payments in Retail Services.
Full year 2024 expense guidance is ~$53.5-53.8 billion (ex-FDIC/Civil Money Penalties), likely at the higher-end.
Cost of Credit guidance for full year 2024 includes an average NCL rate of 3.50-4.00% for Branded Cards and 5.75-6.25% for Retail Services.
Capital strategy involves determining the level of buybacks on a quarter-by-quarter basis.
Medium-term targets include a 4-5% revenue CAGR, an efficiency ratio of <60%, and continued capital benefits from exits and simplification.
The company is committed to an 11-12% RoTCE Medium-Term Target.
This presentation contains "forward-looking statements" based on management's current expectations, which are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

Actual results may differ materially due to various factors, including geopolitical and macroeconomic challenges, execution of strategic initiatives, legal and regulatory outcomes, and other risks detailed in Citigroup's SEC filings.
Citigroup does not undertake to update any forward-looking statements.
Citi has operated in Argentina for over 100 years, serving approximately 1,300 clients, including 700 multinational clients, primarily in liquidity management, payments, and custody services.
In 3Q24, Citibank Argentina sold its remaining position in BOPREAL bonds and returned approximately $0.2 billion of excess capital to its parent entity, reducing future FX devaluation risk.
Citi's net investment in Argentina decreased to $1.3 billion, driven by capital repatriation exceeding income from operations.
As of September 30, 2024, $0.9 billion of Citi's net investment was denominated in local currency, with approximately $0.3B of this exposure hedged.
While YTD peso devaluation has been less significant than in 2023, there remains a potential risk for significant devaluation in 4Q24.
Citi ended nearly all institutional banking services in Russia as of March 31, 2023, and has largely completed wind-downs of its consumer and local commercial banking businesses.
Russia exposure increased by approximately $0.9 billion from the previous quarter to $9.1 billion as of September 30, 2024, primarily due to net increases in Russia unremittable corporate dividends.
Of the $9.1 billion exposure, approximately $7.5 billion (82%) was unremittable corporate dividends.
Net investment in the Russian entity increased by $0.1 billion during 3Q24 to $0.2 billion, driven by earnings on its local cash position.

Citi has a cumulative translation adjustment (CTA) loss balance of approximately $1.6 billion related to its Russian subsidiary, which is recognizable in earnings only upon substantial liquidation or loss of control.
A loss of control of the entity would also result in recognizing a loss of $0.7 billion on intercompany liabilities.
Total average deposits have grown at a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 4.9%.
Services deposits have grown at a CAGR of 5.9%.
ACL: Allowance for Credit Losses
CET1: Common Equity Tier 1
EBT: Earnings before Tax
EPS: Earnings per Share
NII: Net Interest Income
NIR: Non-Interest Revenue
QoQ: Quarter-Over-Quarter
RoTCE: Return on Average Tangible Common Equity
TCE: Tangible Common Equity
YoY: Year-Over-Year
YTD: Year-to-date
Slide 2, Note 1: Represents consumer banking businesses across 14 markets in Asia, Europe, the Middle East and Mexico as part of Citi's strategic refresh.
Slide 3, Note 1: Wallet share based on Dealogic data as of September 30, 2024; wallet share for Debt Capital Markets includes Leveraged Finance and Securitization.
Slide 4, Note 1: RoTCE is a non-GAAP financial measure. For a reconciliation to reported results, please refer to Slide 25.
Slide 4, Note 3: Tangible Book Value Per Share is a non-GAAP financial measure. For a reconciliation of this measure to reported results, please refer to Slide 25.
